<script type="text/javascript">
<!-- Comment to prevent JavaScript from being displayed in old browsers.
function goChangeDisplay() {
    if (document.changeDisplay.displayType.options[document.changeDisplay.displayType.selectedIndex].value != 0) {
        document.changeDisplay.submit();
    }
}

function printDisplay() {
    window.print();
}

function printableResultsWindow() {
    window.open("DisplayPrintableResults.jsp","printableResults","dependent=yes,width=700,height=500,screenX=10,screenY=10,left=10,top=10,menubar=no,resizable=yes,status=no,toolbar=no,scrollbars=yes");
}

function showHelp() {
    window.open("help/helpMain.jsp", "help", "dependent=yes,width=700,height=500,screenX=10,screenY=10,left=10,top=10,menubar=no,resizable=yes,status=no,toolbar=no,scrollbars=yes");
}
function showStats(helpPage) {
    if (helpPage == null) {
	    helpPage="menu.jsp"
		}
		    window.open("help/helpMain.jsp?helpContentURL=" + helpPage, "help", "dependent=yes,width=700,height=500,screenX=10,screenY=10,left=10,top=10,menubar=no,resizable=yes,status=no,toolbar=no,scrollbars=yes");
		    }

function goNewSearch() {
    document.newSearch.submit();
}

function goModifySearch() {
    document.modifySearch.submit();
}

        <div id="aadb">		
          
<BR><p> Results displayed by award category; sort is alphabetical<BR>Win indicated by an asterisk (*)</p><BR>
<dl>
<dt>
<b>ACTOR -- LEADING ROLE</b>
</dt>
<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=1">1927/28 (1st)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1552&BSFromYear=1">ACTOR</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39006">Richard Barthelmess</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34693">The Noose</A></I> {&quot;Nickie Elkins&quot;}; and <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34694">The Patent Leather Kid</A></I> {&quot;The Patent Leather Kid&quot;} </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39008">Emil Jannings</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34691">The Last Command</A></I> {&quot;General Dolgorucki [Grand Duke Sergius Alexander]&quot;}; and <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34707">The Way of All Flesh</A></I> {&quot;August Schilling&quot;} </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1650&BSFromYear=1">SPECIAL AWARD</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39046">To Charles Chaplin, for acting, writing, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>.</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: "The Academy Board of Judges on merit awards for individual achievements in motion picture arts during the year ending August 1, 1928, unanimously decided that your name should be removed from the competitive classes, and that a special first award be conferred upon you for writing, acting, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>.  The collective accomplishments thus displayed place you in a class by yourself."  (Letter from the Academy to Mr. Chaplin, dated February 19, 1929.)]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
</DD>
<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=2">1928/29 (2nd)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1552&BSFromYear=2">ACTOR</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=45062">George Bancroft</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37544">Thunderbolt</A></I> {&quot;Thunderbolt Jim Lang&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.  Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39048">Warner Baxter</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34712">In Old Arizona</A></I> {&quot;The Cisco Kid&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=45063">Chester Morris</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37545">Alibi</A></I> {&quot;No. 1065, Chick Williams&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.  Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=45064">Paul Muni</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37546">The Valiant</A></I> {&quot;James Dyke&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.  Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=45065">Lewis Stone</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34713">The Patriot</A></I> {&quot;Count Pahlen&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.  Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
</DD>
<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=3">1929/30 (3rd)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1552&BSFromYear=3">ACTOR</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39055">George Arliss</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34723">Disraeli</A></I> {&quot;Benjamin Disraeli&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: As allowed by the award rules for this year, a single nomination could honor work in one or more films.  Though the final awards ballot listed both <i>Disraeli</i> and <i>The Green Goddess</i> in his nomination, the award was announced for only the <i>Disraeli</i> performance.  It has never been established as to why this was, but it possibly could have been because the original report from the Acting Branch Board of Judges only listed the <i>Disraeli</i> performance in the results of the nominations voting, or it could have been because on some of the final ballots, the voters had indicated the <i>Disraeli</i> performance over the other.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39056">George Arliss</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34725">The Green Goddess</A></I> {&quot;Oxonian, the Rajah of Rukh&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: As allowed by the award rules for this year, a single nomination could honor work in one or more films.  Though the final awards ballot listed both <i>Disraeli</i> and <i>The Green Goddess</i> in his nomination, the award was announced for only the <i>Disraeli</i> performance.  It has never been established as to why this was, but it possibly could have been because the original report from the Acting Branch Board of Judges only listed the <i>Disraeli</i> performance in the results of the nominations voting, or it could have been because on some of the final ballots, the voters had indicated the <i>Disraeli</i> performance over the other.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">

<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">

There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.  Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=45067">Betty Compson</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37548">The Barker</A></I> {&quot;Carrie&quot;} </DIV>

Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=45068">Jeanne Eagels</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37549">The Letter</A></I> {&quot;Leslie Crosbie&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  There were no announcements of nominations, no certificates of nomination or honorable mention, and only the winners (*) were revealed during the awards banquet on April 3, 1930.  Though not official nominations, the additional names in each category, according to in-house records, were under consideration by the various boards of judges.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>

<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39065">Greta Garbo</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34716">Anna Christie</A></I> {&quot;Anna Christie&quot;}; and <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34732">Romance</A></I> {&quot;Madame Rita Cavallini&quot;} </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39067">Norma Shearer</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34724">The Divorcee</A></I> {&quot;Jerry&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: As allowed by the award rules for this year, a single nomination could honor work in one or more films.  Though the final awards ballot listed both <i>The Divorcee</i> and <i>Their Own Desire</i> in her nomination, the award was announced for only the <i>The Divorcee</i> performance.  It has never been established as to why this was, but it possibly could have been because the original report from the Acting Branch Board of Judges only listed <i>The Divorcee</i> performance in the results of the nominations voting, or it could have been because on some of the final ballots, the voters had indicated the <i>The Divorcee</i> performance over the other.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39068">Norma Shearer</A> -- <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=34737">Their Own Desire</A></I> {&quot;Lucia 'Lally' Marlett&quot;} </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: As allowed by the award rules for this year, a single nomination could honor work in one or more films.  Though the final awards ballot listed both <i>The Divorcee</i> and <i>Their Own Desire</i> in her nomination, the award was announced for only the <i>The Divorcee</i> performance.  It has never been established as to why this was, but it possibly could have been because the original report from the Acting Branch Board of Judges only listed <i>The Divorcee</i> performance in the results of the nominations voting, or it could have been because on some of the final ballots, the voters had indicated the <i>The Divorcee</i> performance over the other.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">

<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36548">Birdman of Alcatraz</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42837">Burnett Guffey</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36559">The Longest Day</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42838">Jean Bourgoin, Walter Wottitz, (Henri Persin)</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: Originally, the three names of Jean Bourgoin, Henri Persin and Walter Wottitz (as listed on the Official Screen Credits form) were announced as nominees for this film in this category.  The credits from the film listed four Directors of Photography (in the following order), Mr. Persin, Mr. Wottitz, Pierre Levent and Mr. Bourgoin.  The program for the Awards ceremony and even the official letter from Price Waterhouse with the results of the final voting for the awards listed the three names as winners in this category.  At some point, the name of Henri Persin was dropped from the nomination, as his name has been "whited-out" from the official wording for the nomination certificates, and the nominations and winners lists the Academy publishes do not include his name.   The Academy's records and files give no reason for this exclusion.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>

<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1650&BSFromYear=1">SPECIAL AWARD</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39046">To Charles Chaplin, for acting, writing, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>.</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: "The Academy Board of Judges on merit awards for individual achievements in motion picture arts during the year ending August 1, 1928, unanimously decided that your name should be removed from the competitive classes, and that a special first award be conferred upon you for writing, acting, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>.  The collective accomplishments thus displayed place you in a class by yourself."  (Letter from the Academy to Mr. Chaplin, dated February 19, 1929.)]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=40224">To Rey Scott for his extraordinary achievement in producing <i>Kukan</i>, the film record of China's struggle, including its photography with a 16mm camera under the most difficult and dangerous conditions.</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=40225">To The British Ministry of Information for its vivid and dramatic presentation of the heroism of the RAF in the documentary film, <i>Target for Tonight</i>.</A> </DIV>

<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=41">1968 (41st)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1573&BSFromYear=41">DOCUMENTARY (Feature)</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36889">A Few Notes on Our Food Problem</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=43565">James Blue, Producer</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36890">Journey into Self</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=43566">Bill McGaw, Producer</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: At the 41st Awards ceremony on April 14, 1969, <i>Young Americans</i> was announced as the winner of the Documentary Feature Oscar.  On May 7, 1969, the film was declared ineligible after it was revealed that the film had played in October of 1967, therefore ineligible for a 1968 Award.  The first runner-up, <i>Journey into Self</i>, was awarded the statuette on May 8, 1969.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36891">The Legendary Champions</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=43568">William Cayton, Producer</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36892">Other Voices</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=43569">David H. Sawyer, Producer</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36893">Young Americans</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=43567">Robert Cohn and Alex Grasshoff, Producers</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  At the 41st Awards ceremony on April 14, 1969, <i>Young Americans</i> was announced as the winner of the Documentary Feature Oscar.  On May 7, 1969, the film was declared ineligible after it was revealed that the film had played in October of 1967, therefore ineligible for a 1968 Award.  The first runner-up, <i>Journey into Self</i>, was awarded the statuette on May 8, 1969.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
</DD>

<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1573&BSFromYear=43">DOCUMENTARY (Feature)</A></td>

<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36148">Genevieve</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=41908">Larry Adler</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: Because of the political climate of the times, <i>Genevieve</i>'s arranger and orchestra conductor Muir Mathieson was credited as composer on American prints of this British-made film, and was thus credited with the nomination.  In June of 1986, the Board of Governors had Academy records updated to give Larry Adler his proper credit, which Mr. Mathieson had never claimed.  Mr. Mathieson's name was removed from the nomination and Mr. Adler's inserted.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>

<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=45">1972 (45th)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1583&BSFromYear=45">MUSIC (Original Dramatic Score)</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37057">The Godfather</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=46379">Nino Rota</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  <i>The Godfather</i> score, composed by Nino Rota, was originally announced as one of the five official nominees.  It was later pointed out that portions of the score and the main theme were composed by Rota for his score to the 1958 Italian film, <i>Fortunella</i>.  The Music Branch was given this information and re-balloted to determine the fifth nomination.  The list of six films they were to choose from were the remaining five of the top ten preliminary listings, plus <i>The Godfather</i> score.  The results of the re-balloting was that the fifth nomination became <i>Sleuth</i>, composed by John Addison.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=37088">images</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=44012">John Williams</A> </DIV>

<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: <i>The Godfather</i> score, composed by Nino Rota, was originally announced as one of the five official nominees.  It was later pointed out that portions of the score and the main theme were composed by Rota for his score to the 1958 Italian film, <i>Fortunella</i>.  The Music Branch was given this information and re-balloted to determine the fifth nomination.  The list of six films they were to choose from were the remaining five of the top ten preliminary listings, plus <i>The Godfather</i> score.  The results of the re-balloting was that the fifth nomination became <i>Sleuth</i>, composed by John Addison.]</DIV>

<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><div class="nomHangIndent">&quot;Pig Foot Pete&quot; from <I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=35331">Hellzapoppin'</A></I> -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=47499">Music by Gene de Paul; Lyrics by Don Raye</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: This nomination is a mystery.  Both the nominations list and the program from the Awards dinner list the song as being from <i>Hellzapoppin'</i>, a 1942 release for Awards purposes.  The song does not appear in that film, but did appear in <i>Keep 'Em Flying</i>, a 1941 release from the same production company and studio, and was therefore ineligible for a 1942 nomination.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>

<dt>
<b>SOUND</b>
</dt>
<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=3">1929/30 (3rd)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>

</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=39046">To Charles Chaplin, for acting, writing, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>.</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: "The Academy Board of Judges on merit awards for individual achievements in motion picture arts during the year ending August 1, 1928, unanimously decided that your name should be removed from the competitive classes, and that a special first award be conferred upon you for writing, acting, directing and producing <i>The Circus</i>.  The collective accomplishments thus displayed place you in a class by yourself."  (Letter from the Academy to Mr. Chaplin, dated February 19, 1929.)]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>

<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1629&BSFromYear=26">WRITING (Motion Picture Story)</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36081">Above and Beyond</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=41809">Beirne Lay, Jr.</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36105">The Captain's Paradise</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=41810">Alec Coppel</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36106">Hondo</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=41831">Louis L'Amour</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  Originally announced on February 15, 1954 as a nominee in this category.  On February 17, 1954, letters from the producer and the nominee questioned its inclusion in the (original) motion picture story category, as it was based on the short story, "The Gift of Cochise," by the nominee, published in Collier's magazine on July 5, 1952.  By waiver, the title of the short story was not included in the film's credits.  The nomination was withdrawn, and only four titles were included on the final ballot.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36107">Little Fugitive</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=41811">Ray Ashley, Morris Engel, Ruth Orkin</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36058">Roman Holiday</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=41812">Dalton Trumbo</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: The screen credit and award were originally credited to Ian McLellan Hunter, who was a "front" for Dalton Trumbo.  On December 15, 1992, the Academy's Board of Governors voted to change the records and award Mr. Trumbo with the achievement.  Ian McLellan Hunter's name was removed from the Motion Picture Story category.  The Oscar was posthumously presented to Trumbo's widow on May 10, 1993.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>

<dt>
<A CLASS="awardYearHeader" TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSFromYear=29">1956 (29th)</A></dt>
<table class="noteIndent" cols="2" width="95%" border=0>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1629&BSFromYear=29">WRITING (Motion Picture Story)</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36254">The Brave One</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42196">Dalton Trumbo</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: The name of the writer credited with authorship, Robert Rich, turned out to be an alias.  Two decades later, the mystery was officially solved and the Academy statuette went (on May 2, 1975, presented by then Academy president Walter Mirisch) to its rightful owner, screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, blacklisted in 1956 by the industry for political affiliations.  Robert Rich (who had nothing to do with the film industry) is a nephew of the King Brothers, producers of the film.  They chose his name to be the alias for Dalton Trumbo on the screenplay.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36251">The Eddy Duchin Story</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42197">Leo Katcher</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36277">High Society</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42198">Edward Bernds, Elwood Ullman</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: THIS IS NOT AN OFFICIAL NOMINATION.  Edward Bernds and Elwood Ullman, the authors of this Bowery Boys quickie, respectfully withdrew their own names and the nomination, aware that voters had probably mistaken their film with a 1956 MGM release with the same title written by John Patrick and starring Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly and Frank Sinatra.  (Even so, MGM's <i>High Society</i> would only have been eligible for adapted screenplay.)]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36278">The Proud and the Beautiful</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42199">Jean Paul Sartre</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36279">Umberto D.</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42200">Cesare Zavattini</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" valign="TOP">
<A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=1&BSCategoryExact=1634&BSFromYear=29">WRITING (Screenplay--Adapted)</A></td>
</tr>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30">*</td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36247">Around the World in 80 Days</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42201">James Poe, John Farrow, S.J. Perelman</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36238">Baby Doll</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42202">Tennessee Williams</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36235">Friendly Persuasion</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42205">Michael Wilson</A> </DIV>
<DIV CLASS="noteIndent">[NOTE: Early in 1956, the name of blacklisted screenwriter Michael Wilson had been deleted from the screen credits of <i>Friendly Persuasion</i> by Allied Artists, the film's distributor, based on a 1952 agreement between the Screen Writers Guild and various production companies.  That agreement gave studios the right to omit from the screen the name of any individual who had failed to clear himself before a duly constituted legislative committee of Congress if accused of Communist affiliations, as was the case with Wilson at the time.  The Academy, in the awkward position of possibly conferring its highest honor on someone whose name had been omitted from screen credit, revised its bylaws at a special February 6, 1957, meeting.  That revision, in essence, allowed that in such cases, the achievement itself could be eligible for nomination, but the specific writer would be ineligible.  The following instructions were sent to Price Waterhouse & Co., Certified Public Accountants, who tabulated Academy ballots:  "...we ask that if, in tabulating the nominations ballots for Best Screenplay (adapted), <i>Friendly Persuasion</i> is one of the five nominations, you list the other four alphabetically by title and below: <i>Friendly Persuasion</i> - Achievement nominated, but writer ineligible for Award under Academy By-Laws."  On February 17, 1957, the Academy's Board of Governors voted to instruct Price Waterhouse & Co. "...to list five nominations, and in the event that one of these is declared ineligible under the By-Law provision, four nominations would appear on the final ballot."  THIS NOMINATION WAS NOT INCLUDED ON THE FINAL BALLOT.  (The bylaw was repealed by the Academy as "unworkable" on January 12, 1959.)  On December 10, 2002, the Academy's Board of Governors voted to reinstate Mr. Wilson's nomination.]</DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36231">Giant</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42203">Fred Guiol, Ivan Moffat</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
<tr valign="TOP">
<td align="RIGHT" width="30"></td><td><DIV CLASS="nomHangIndent"><I><A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=3&BSFilmID=36232">Lust for Life</A></I>  -- <A TARGET="_top" HREF="BasicSearch?action=searchLink&displayType=6&BSNominationID=42204">Norman Corwin</A> </DIV>
</TD></TR>
